title: A defiant Andy King plans lawsuit over ethics probe
text:
New York City Council Member Andy King is facing an ethics inquiry. | Andrew Burton/Getty Images A defiant Andy King plans lawsuit over ethics probe

Council Member Andy King and his attorney vowed to sue the City Council over its handling of an ethics inquiry during a defiant and emotionally charged press conference Saturday.

The Bronx lawmaker gathered with family and supporters in his district at the New Testament Temple Church of God to declare his innocence and urge his colleagues to vote against a set of disciplinary measures on Monday that are being recommended in response to the probe.

Story Continued Below

“What I’m going through, what my family is going through, is just not fair,” King said, calling the last three months a period of personal turmoil and touting his record of service in the community. “We’re being mistreated. We’re being treated like we are some type of criminal … and that’s far from who I am as a person.”

The Council’s Committee on Standards and Ethics, along with outside prosecutor Carrie Cohen, released a report this week accusing King of a wide range of improprieties, including misusing government resources, allowing his wife to conduct official Council business and then retaliating against staffers who he believed were cooperating with the probe.

Pamela Hayes, King’s attorney, argued at the news conference that the Council member did not have adequate time to mount a defense and was being unfairly portrayed as uncooperative, a qualm that will be the central premise of an Article 78 lawsuit to be filed on Monday.

“I will give you an old-fashioned saying that most litigation people use: If they don’t get it right, we’ll see them in court,” she said, indicating that the legal salvo will be designed to hold up the disciplinary process until a judge can examine what took place.

Hayes, for example, said the special counsel and the committee refused to reschedule meetings if King and his lawyers had conflicts. And in one instance, when the lawmaker was set to meet with investigators, they were kept waiting for three hours before being told that the committee and special counsel were not coming.

“I have not been able to give my side of the story that is in this document,” King said Saturday, adding that he was not told of a closed-door meeting with Council members this week to discuss the case. “Something is wrong with that process.”

However, the committee wrote in its report that King’s lawyers had been aware of the investigation for months and were given ample time to prepare for a closed-door hearing, which was scheduled nearly three weeks after a set of updated charges were announced on Aug. 21. In fact, Cohen and the committee argued, the lawmaker’s attorneys had deliberately avoided coming in to create the impression that King was being deprived of his due process rights.

“Council Member King’s attorneys engaged in a pattern of dilatory and non-responsive behavior designed to delay the hearing indefinitely and frustrate the Council’s disciplinary process as well as a calculated attempt to lay a foundation to make the false allegations of denial of due process,” the report said.

King and his lawyers had already taken steps to sue the committee over due process matters in recent weeks, he said in one of several arguments that King was being unfairly singled out for punishment by a committee that had ignored other complaints. King said, for example, that he had filed a complaint after being the subject of a racial slur in City Hall. He said his staff have also lodged complaints with the committee to no avail.

The Council is set to vote during a special stated meeting Monday on the recommended punishment, which includes a 30-day suspension, a $15,000 fine, the installation of a monitor over King’s office, his removal from all committees, a guarantee that staffers can return to their old jobs and a prohibition on requiring employees to chauffeur King to official events in their personal vehicles without reimbursement.

King urged his colleagues to oppose the measure Monday and give what he argued is enough time to adequately address the allegations against him.

“We need a 'no' vote for Monday,” he said. “We need [members] to adhere to justice, truth, and fair practice and the process. And that has not been established since day one. That’s all we’re asking for.”

The special counsel’s case is based off of both documentary evidence — such as emails that the report alleges show staffers used Council resources to plan a retreat in the Virgin Islands — and testimony from employees who said they witnessed King compare a photo from the city’s Pride Parade to child pornography, among other allegations. Council Member Steven Matteo, who chairs the ethics committee, called the witnesses “credible and damning.”

The punishment planned for King is among the most severe in the Council’s history, topping a suite of disciplinary measures directed at former Council Member Allan Jennings, who was found in 2005 to have repeatedly sexually harassed female staffers.

Council Speaker Corey Johnson and Mayor Bill de Blasio have called on King to resign while Council Member Jimmy Van Bramer and Susan Lerner, head of good government group Common Cause, have called on the body to go further and expel King.

But the question of whether the Council should remove an official who has won an election — in this case three times — has raised questions about subverting the democratic process.

“Since we voted for him, he clearly represents us,” Rev. Paul Peart, senior pastor at the New Testament Temple Church of God, said at Saturday’s rally. “So if you touch him, you touch us. When you disrespect him, you disrespect us. If you undermine him, you undermine us. And we will be watching. And we will be voting.”

Johnson said last week that the standard for expulsion would likely need to involve criminal charges by an outside enforcement body — similar to the felony charges that automatically removed former Council Member Ruben Wills from office in 2017. And while Johnson said investigators had made referrals to outside agencies, King’s attorney said Saturday that she did not believe they had been contacted by anyone outside the Council.
